required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Study on the Possible Health Effects of Lean Fish and Fatty Fish Intake in Overweight or Obese Adults
clinical_study.official_title: Fiskespisestudiene 2011-2014. Spiseforsøk Med Fisk. Delstudie 2: Studie av Mulige Effekter av Fet og Mager Fisk på Glukosemetabolismen og inflammasjonsmarkører i Overvektige Voksne.

brief_summary.textblock:
The potential health effects of high intake of lean or fatty fish will be investigated in overweight or obese adults. Participants consume 750g/week of fillets of fish for 8 weeks.
Hypothesis:
High intake of fatty or lean fish will beneficially affect glucose regulation and the immune system.

primary_outcome.measure: Changes in serum concentrations of glucose

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in insulin, insulin C-peptide, leukocyte fatty acids, leukocyte function, body weight and composition, and intake of energy and macronutrients within the groups over time.
Changes in serum vitamin concentrations after fish intake.
secondary_outcome.description: Serum concentrations of fat-soluble and water-soluble vitamins were measured, and dietary intakes of vitamins were estimated based on reported food intake from 5-day food diaries.

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in serum and urine concentrations of amino acids and metabolites of amino acids after fish intake.
secondary_outcome.description: Concentrations of amino acids and amino acid metabolites were measured in fasting serum and morning urine

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in fecal microbiota profile after fish intake.
secondary_outcome.description: 54 DNA bacterial markers targeting more than 300 bacteria based on their 16S rRNA sequence in seven variable regions were analysed in feces (72h collection)

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in fecal and serum concentrations of lipids and bile acids after fish intake.
secondary_outcome.description: Fat, cholesterol and total bile acids were quantified in feces (72h collection) and fasting serum.

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in markers of oxidative stress after fish intake.
secondary_outcome.description: Antioxidant enzymes, antioxidant enzyme cofactors and biomarkers of oxidative stress were quantified in serum

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in total neopterin after fish intake
secondary_outcome.description: Total neopterin was measured in serum.

secondary_outcome.measure: Quantification of markers of kidney dysfunction
secondary_outcome.description: Urine concentrations of cystatin C and T-cell immunoglobulin mucin-1 (relative to creatinine) were measured as markers of kidney function

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in amino acids and metabolites of amino acids after a standardized meal.
secondary_outcome.description: Concentrations of amino acids and amino acid metabolites were measured in fasting and postprandial serum

arm_group.description: Participants eat 750g of lean fish per week for 8 weeks.
Participants eat 750g of fatty fish per week for 8 weeks.
Participants eat as normal, but avoid fish and seafood for 8 weeks.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- BMI ≥27 kg/m2
- fasting blood glucose ≤7.0 mmol/L
Exclusion Criteria:
- pregnancy
- incompatibility with fish consumption (allergies, intolerance and/or dislike)
- diagnosed diabetes mellitus, heart disease or gastrointestinal diseases
- use of medications affecting lipid metabolism or glucose homeostasis
- use of anti-inflammatory medications
- use of supplements containing long chain n-3 fatty acids
- intentional weight loss
- and large fluctuation in body weight (>3 kg) over the previous two months
